newsitem.title: UK: TENNIS-RAIN THREATENS ANOTHER DAY'S PLAY AT WIMBLEDON.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-RAIN THREATENS ANOTHER DAY'S PLAY AT WIMBLEDON.

text.p: Wimbledon's miserable first week continued on Saturday with yet more rain holding up the start of play.
Organisers of the Grand Slam event had hoped to start promptly at 1000 GMT in a bid to eat into the huge backlog of matches after Thursday and Friday were washed out completely.
Only two matches were completed on Wednesday and many players have yet to get through the first round. The championships are now some 260 matches behind schedule.
But Saturday morning saw more rain and organisers announced the start would be delayed.
Saturday's weather forecast said there could be bright spells in the afternoon but warned that there was also the risk of thunder and more showers.
Officials at the championships have said they will decide by 1500 GMT on Saturday whether to play on Sunday, traditionally a rest day.
In 1991, after rain had disrupted the first four days of play, the All England Club decided to hold matches on the middle Sunday for the first time.
The move was a huge success with tennis fans who queued all night for the cheap tickets and created a carnival atmosphere on Centre Court.

But this year the weather forecast for Sunday is for more rain and the organisers may decide instead to look at other options such as extending the championships into a third week or cutting some rounds of the men's singles to the best of three sets.
If the weather brightens up on Saturday, Natasha Zvereva of Belarus and Elena Likhovtseva of Russia are due out first on Centre Court to finish a first-round match that began on Wednesday.
American teenager Venus Williams, who has been waiting to play since Monday, is scheduled first on the new Court One, against Poland's Magdalena Grzybowska.
